prompt: Plastic waste is a problem because:
answers: Non-biodegradable; persists, harms wildlife, microplastics enter food chain
explanation: Plastic persists for centuries, harms wildlife (ingestion, entanglement), and breaks into microplastics that enter the food chain and environment.

prompt: Solid Waste Management Rules in India are notified under:
explanation: Solid Waste Management Rules and other waste rules are notified by the central government under the Environment (Protection) Act, 1986.

answers: Toxic metals (lead, mercury, cadmium) and valuable metals (gold, copper); needs safe handling
explanation: E-waste (electronic waste) contains hazardous substances (lead, mercury, cadmium) and valuable materials. Improper recycling causes pollution and health risks.

prompt: E-Waste (Management) Rules in India aim to:
answers: Regulate e-waste handling, recycling; extended producer responsibility (EPR)
explanation: E-Waste (Management) Rules regulate collection, recycling, and disposal. They include Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) making producers responsible for end-of-life products.

answers: Hazardous and Other Wastes (Management) Rules; Basel Convention
explanation: Hazardous waste in India is regulated under the Hazardous and Other Wastes (Management) Rules. International movement is governed by the Basel Convention.

answers: Infectious waste from hospitals (needles, tissues, chemicals)
explanation: Biomedical waste includes infectious and hazardous waste from healthcare—needles, syringes, tissues, blood, chemicals. It is regulated under Biomedical Waste Management Rules.
3R stands for Reduce (less waste), Reuse (use again), Recycle (convert to new product). It is a hierarchy for sustainable waste management.

answers: Site for disposal of waste by burying; can cause leachate and methane
explanation: A landfill is a designated site where waste is buried. Poorly managed landfills can produce leachate (contaminating groundwater) and methane (greenhouse gas).

answers: Burns waste; reduces volume but can release pollutants if not controlled
explanation: Incineration burns waste, reducing volume and sometimes generating energy. Without proper controls it can release dioxins and other pollutants.

answers: Biological decomposition of organic waste into nutrient-rich compost
explanation: Composting is the natural process of decomposing organic waste (food, garden waste) into compost that can be used to enrich soil.

answers: Cleanliness, open defecation free (ODF), solid waste management (rural and urban)
explanation: Swachh Bharat Mission (Clean India Mission) aims at eliminating open defecation, improving solid waste management, and promoting cleanliness in rural and urban areas.

answers: Cleaning and rejuvenating the Ganga river (pollution abatement, sewage, afforestation)
explanation: Namami Gange is a flagship programme for the conservation and rejuvenation of the Ganga—sewage treatment, pollution control, and sustainable management.

prompt: Marine plastic pollution is addressed by:
answers: International efforts; India has coastal and plastic waste rules
explanation: Marine plastic is addressed through national rules (waste management, plastic bans) and international initiatives. UNEA has discussed a global plastic treaty.

answers: Plastic used once and discarded (bags, straws, cutlery)
explanation: Single-use plastics are designed to be used once and then discarded—e.g. carry bags, straws, disposable cutlery. Many countries are restricting or banning them.

answers: Producer responsible for product at end of life (collection, recycling)
explanation: EPR makes producers responsible for the entire life cycle of their products, including take-back, recycling, or safe disposal at end of life.

prompt: Plastic waste management rules in India promote:
answers: Segregation, recycling, EPR, phase-out of certain plastics
explanation: Plastic Waste Management Rules promote segregation, recycling, use of recycled content, and EPR. Some single-use items have been phased out.

answers: Liquid that percolates through waste; can contaminate groundwater if not collected
explanation: Leachate is the liquid that drains from a landfill as water percolates through waste. It can contain toxic substances and must be collected and treated.

answers: Convert waste to energy (heat/electricity) through incineration or biogas; need emission controls
explanation: Waste-to-energy facilities burn waste to generate heat or electricity. They can reduce landfill volume but require strict emission controls.

prompt: Segregation of waste at source means:
answers: Separating waste (dry/wet, recyclable) at point of generation
explanation: Source segregation means separating waste (e.g. dry and wet, or recyclables) where it is generated (home, office) to enable recycling and proper treatment.

answers: Tiny plastic particles (often from breakdown of larger plastic); found in water, soil, organisms
explanation: Microplastics are small plastic particles (typically under 5 mm). They come from breakdown of larger plastic or from products (e.g. microbeads) and are found globally in water and organisms.
